aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Report for Aeronca 7AC in Maryville, Tennessee
The accident occurred in Maryville, Tennessee.
The accident occurred on October 4, 2014, at 18:10 Local time.
The aircraft involved was an Aeronca 7AC.
The defining event of the accident was loss of lift.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Instructional.
The accident number was ERA15CA007.
The aircraft registration was N85707.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
The accident resulted in 2 minor injuries.
The pilot/owner had purchased the airplane a few weeks prior to the accident.
The flight was to accomplish training in a conventional landing gear airplane.
During the training flight, numerous takeoffs and landings were accomplished at various airports in the area.
While on the final leg of the traffic pattern, the flight instructor (CFI) commanded a go-around maneuver.
The pilot/owner stated that he "had the landing."
The CFI again instructed that the go-around maneuver be performed.
The CFI advanced the throttle to full power.
The pilot/owner applied back pressure and maintained the best rate of climb.
According to the CFI, the pilot/owner was informed that the airplane was "high and hot" on final.
After repeating that the airplane was "high and hot," the throttle was advanced by the pilot/owner.
A go-around maneuver began after the throttle was advanced.
Neither the pilot/owner nor the CFI remembered advancing the throttle.
The airplane impacted approximately 60-foot tall trees at the departure end of the runway.
The airplane nosed over after impacting the trees.
The airplane came to rest inverted at the base of the trees.
The crash resulted in substantial damage to the fuselage, wings, and rudder.
The intended runway had a 42 foot incline.
There were residences on the left side of the runway.
There were high tension powerlines on the right side of the runway.
Both pilots reported that there were no mechanical malfunctions or abnormalities that would have precluded normal operation.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of this accident to be the pilot/owner's failure to maintain a stabilized approach during the final leg of the traffic pattern.
Both pilots' lack of aeronautical decision making contributed to the accident.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Maryville, Tennessee

## Date & Time: 
October 4, 2014, 18:10 Local

## Aircraft:
Aeronca 7AC

## Defining Event:
Loss of lift

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Instructional

## Accident Number:
ERA15CA007

## Registration:
N85707

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
2 Minor

## Analysis

According to the pilot/owner, he had purchased the airplane a few weeks prior to the accident and the flight was to accomplish training in a conventional landing gear airplane. During the training flight, numerous takeoffs and landings were accomplished at various airports in the area. While on the final leg of the traffic pattern the flight instructor (CFI) commanded a go-around maneuver and the pilot/owner stated that he "had the landing." The CFI again instructed that the go-around maneuver be performed and he advanced the throttle to full power. The pilot/owner applied back pressure and maintained the best rate of climb. According to the CFI, the pilot/owner was informed that the airplane was "high and hot" on final, after repeating that, the throttle was advanced, by the pilot/owner, and a go-around maneuver began. Neither of the pilots remembered advancing the throttle. The airplane impacted the approximate 60-foot tall trees at the departure end of the runway and nosed over, coming to rest inverted at the base of the trees, which resulted in substantial damage to the fuselage, wings, and rudder. The intended runway had a 42 foot incline, residence on the left side, and high tension powerlines on the right side. Both pilots reported that there were no mechanical malfunctions or abnormalities that would have precluded normal operation.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:The pilot/owner's failure to maintain a stabilized approach during the final leg of the traffic pattern. Contributing to the accident was both pilot's lack of aeronautical decision making.

---
